Answer: <<<api>>>: PackageManager.getInstalledApplications()
<<<code>>>: 
```java
ArrayList<String> appList = new ArrayList<String>();
List<ApplicationInfo> packages = getPackageManager().getInstalledApplications(PackageManager.GET_META_DATA);
for (ApplicationInfo packageInfo : packages) {
    if ((packageInfo.flags & ApplicationInfo.FLAG_SYSTEM) == 0) {
        appList.add(getPackageManager().getApplicationLabel(packageInfo).toString());
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code will get all the applications installed on the device and add their names to an ArrayList. The flag FLAG_SYSTEM is used to exclude system applications.

However, this will only give you the names of the applications. If you want to get the icons, you can use the loadIcon method of the PackageManager. Here is how you can modify the code:
```java
ArrayList<AppInfo> appList = new ArrayList<AppInfo>();
List<ApplicationInfo> packages = getPackageManager().getInstalledApplications(PackageManager.GET_META_DATA);
for (ApplicationInfo packageInfo : packages) {
    if ((packageInfo.flags & ApplicationInfo.FLAG_SYSTEM) == 0) {
        AppInfo app = new AppInfo();
        app.setName(getPackageManager().getApplicationLabel(packageInfo).toString());
        app.setIcon(getPackageManager().getApplicationIcon(packageInfo));
        appList.add(app);
    }
}
```
In this code, AppInfo is a custom class that has two properties: name and icon. You can create this class as follows:
```java
public class AppInfo {
    private String name;
    private Drawable icon;

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }

    public void setName(String name) {
        this.name = name;
    }

    public Drawable getIcon() {
        return icon;
    }

    public void setIcon(Drawable icon) {
        this.icon = icon;
    }
}
```
This code will give you a list of AppInfo objects, each containing the name and icon of an application. You can then use this list to populate your ListView.
